close_symbols: struct MHD_Daemon (fields: connections_tail, connections, connection_limit, at_limit, shutdown, listen_fd, was_quiesced, urh_tail, itc)
enum constants: MHD_EVENT_LOOP_INFO_READ, MHD_EVENT_LOOP_INFO_PROCESS_READ, MHD_EVENT_LOOP_INFO_WRITE, MHD_EVENT_LOOP_INFO_PROCESS, MHD_EVENT_LOOP_INFO_CLEANUP
Preprocessor symbols affecting loop presence: MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS, MHD_POSIX_SOCKETS, HTTPS_SUPPORT, UPGRADE_SUPPORT
explanation:
To decide whether each for loop is MISRA‑compliant we must know the loop counters and any objects used or modified in the loop body or the loop clauses, and whether called functions or types can modify those objects. Hence:

- struct MHD_Connection (prev, socket_fd, event_loop_info): The for loops iterate using pos and posn derived from connection->prev. We must know the type/layout and semantics of prev (the auxiliary used in the third clause) and whether event_loop_info or socket_fd accesses in the body can, directly or indirectly, modify prev.

- struct MHD_Daemon (connections_tail, connections, connection_limit, at_limit, shutdown, listen_fd, was_quiesced, urh_tail, itc): The loops start from daemon->connections_tail and daemon->urh_tail and their presence/behaviour depends on these fields. Some loop conditions later check daemon->connections etc.; these fields affect whether loops execute and whether loop counters are altered elsewhere.

- enum constants for event_loop_info cases: Knowing which case labels can be hit tells which functions/statements are executed inside the loop body (e.g. calls that may have side effects). This is necessary because MISRA treats the behaviour of called functions as part of the loop body.

- MHD_add_to_fd_set_ (prototype and side‑effects): This function is called repeatedly inside the loop. To apply MISRA rule 1–4 we must know whether it can modify any objects used in the loop clauses (notably connection->prev or any global that changes pos/posn), or otherwise produce side effects that affect loop counters/auxiliaries.

- struct MHD_UpgradeResponseHandle (prev) and urh_to_fdset (prototype and side‑effects): There is a second for loop over urh_tail using urh->prev. We need the urh structure and whether urh_to_fdset can modify urh or urh->prev (i.e. objects used in the loop clauses).

- Preprocessor symbols (MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS, MHD_POSIX_SOCKETS, HTTPS_SUPPORT, UPGRADE_SUPPORT): These control whether additional loops/branches exist (e.g. extra iteration over connections for W32 or the urh loop). The presence/absence of those blocks changes which loops must be checked for MISRA compliance.

These symbols are the minimal additional information required to determine whether any for loop in internal_get_fdset2 uses objects in the second/third clause that are modified in the loop body (directly or via called functions) or otherwise violates the single loop‑counter / no modification rules of the MISRA clause.
